creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly given to the Center by the Peter F. Drucker Family
description: landscape with waterfalls at URQ, rounded mountains in ULQ, two figures on a bridge in LLQ and trees in LRQ
inscription: 水沽石澗澗□乱  / 葉落雲山山□奇  / 溼翁橋上何処去  / 有箇西邨未決碁 (The water is gone from the stony river that has a disorderly look. / The leaves are gone from the mountain that has a wonderful scene. / The thoroughly wet old man on the bridge, where will he go? / There is a western village where an unsettled game of Go is waiting for him. / Tenth month, 1840)  (trans. Nishimura Masato)
markings: a: 粛字子羽 [Shukuji Shiu]; b: 半江 [Hankō]
text:
Okada Hankō’s monumental work is a tour de force in the spirit of the Four Wangs, a circle of conservative Chinese painters who created stylized interpretations of classic works. This painting follows orthodox principles of composition—the foreground, middle-ground, and background are distinct yet well-integrated—maintaining order in this otherwise fantastical, complex setting. 
 
The inscription reads: 
The water is gone from the stony river that has a disorderly look.
The leaves are gone from the mountain that has a wonderful scene.
The thoroughly wet old man on the bridge, where will he go'
There is a western village where an unsettled game of Go is waiting for him.
Tenth month, 1840
(translated by Masato Nishimura)
title: Landscape after the Four Wangs
